journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Recent developments in the reverse micro-electrical discharge machining in the fabrication of arrayed micro-features

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai 400076, India. email: ssjoshi@iitb.ac.in

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: High aspect ratio arrayed micro-structures and textured surfaces are required in diversified applications such as electrical contacts, printing heads, electrodes for micro-batteries, injection nozzles, nano-material delivery systems, biomedical implants, and hydrophobic surfaces. Reverse micro-electrical discharge machining (R-MEDM) process has a capability to fabricate such arrayed features on a variety of workpiece materials irrespective of their mechanical properties. R-MEDM is a variant of micro-electrical discharge machining (MEDM) process, key difference being, extruded arrayed features are fabricated in the R-MEDM process against the micro-cavities that are machined in MEDM. This article highlights the recent advances in process characterization and modelling of mechanics of the R-MEDM process. The focus of discussion is on comparing the process with the other micromachining processes presently available for the fabrication of arrayed micro-features. In addition, R-MEDM process characteristics in the fabrication of arrayed features on ‘easy’ and ‘difficult’ to erode materials are presented. It is understood that R-MEDM has comparable or in some cases better performance in the fabrication of arrayed features than the processes like micro-milling, micro-wire EDM, micro-wire electrical discharge grinding (EDG) and block EDG.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In micro-electrical discharge machining (MEDM), and its variant processes, material erosion is achieved by repeated sparks struck between electrodes immersed in a dielectric medium. In the case ofreverse micro-electrical discharge machining (R-MEDM) process, a variant of MEDM, a tool is formed by machining micro-cavities on a plate electrode (cathode) using a suitable micromachining process. A large-sized workpiece (anode) is aligned over the cavities and is fed through the cavities at a controlled feed. Selective material erosion is achieved on the anode where electrode interface (anode to cathode) is present. Hence, the cross-section of the fabricated microelectrode array is a reverse replica of cross-section of the micro-hole array on the tool. The aspect ratio of the fabricated structures can be controlled by controlling the displacement of the moving electrode along the Z-axis. In MEDM process, normally electrode rotation is found to be advantageous to flush the dielectric through machining zone and dispel the debris [1]. However, in the case of R-MEDM, electrode rotation is not feasible (especially for arrayed structures) and machining over a large surface causes machining instability. Currently, the process mechanics of material removal in R-MEDM and the role of debris in the process have not been fully understood.

The demonstration of process capability of R-MEDM and the study of the effect of electrical parameters, namely, voltage and capacitance on process stability in R-MEDM, have been credited to Kim et al. [2]. They fabricated a number of features including micro-rods of less than 30 µm on WC as well as unsymmetrical arrayed features using R-MEDM process. Yi et al. [3] successfully fabricated 3 × 3 and 4 × 4 arrays on Cu using 100 µm thick AISI 303 stainless steel foils, which in turn were used for machining 6 × 6 and 16 × 16 cavity patterns on metal foils forapplications in organic thin-film transistors (OTFTs). Simultaneous machining of cavities resulted in five times improvement in the productivity of MEDM. R-MEDM process has been further improved by Zeng et al. [4] by providing ultrasonic vibrations to the plate electrode. Using vibrations at 20 kHz and 1 µm amplitude with R-MEDM improved the surface finish and reduced the processing duration by 2.5 times. In another study, Zeng et al. [5] showed that the machining time reduced with an increase in voltage and capacitance in the ultrasonically assisted R-MEDM process. However, they observed that increasing the amplitude of vibrations above 0.4 µm did not further improve the process significantly. An array of 40 × 40 (1600 pins of Ø30 µm, length 625 µm, and pitch 100 µm) on WC over 6.8 × 6.8 mm2 area was fabricated using R-MEDM by Hwang et al. [6]. Vibration-assisted mechanical peck-drilling (VAMPD) was used to micro-drill the 40 × 40 hole array on 0.6 mm brass plate, which was used as a cathode. In addition, other process improvements were achieved by modifying micro-cavities on plate electrodes and using advanced dielectric flushing techniques.

It is known that accurate microelectrode arrays are required in various micro-engineering fields ranging from mechanical to biomedical. A summary of applications of these arrayed features is presented in Table 1. In most of the applications, highly accurate arrayed features with a good surface finish and without any contamination are required. R-MEDM process involves a number of research issues which include dimensional inaccuracies, low erosion rate, difficulties in preparation of tool electrode, tool wear, and machining instability. This article highlights the research issues, recent advances in process characterization, modelling of the mechanics of material removal, and strategies to improve the process quality and accuracy. Table 1
Applications of arrayed micro-features
Structure geometry Area of application Reference
3D arrayed micro-features with varying cross-sections • Tools in micro-ECM process for machining cavities Kim et al. [2]
• Through holes for passing wires for interfacing devices in MEMS Liu et al. [7]
• Tools in micro-milling applications Fleischer et al. [8]
• Tools in micro-EDM for micro-slitting operation
Microelectrode and micro-hole array • Interface device for capturing neural signals Zeng et al. [4, 5]
• Brain neural activity recording Fofonoff et al. [9, 10],
•Recording device designed for motor cortex studies in non-human primates Masuzawa et al. [11]
• Micro-holes (50 µm diameter on 600 µm thin plates) are used as spray nozzles in biotechnology applications Liu et al. [7, 12]
• Serve as the holding sites for the test agent; reduced hole size can carry number of tests, help to reduce the testing cost and save the reagent Penache et al. [13]
• Stable high-pressure plasma
High aspect ratio micro-rods of hard materials • As an element in various MEMS applications Takeuchi et al. [14]
• Shaft of micro-robot, micro-actuator, a micro-needle for syringe Masuzawa [15]
• As a tool for generating burr-free high aspect ratio holes
• Mechanical punch to perforate thin foils
Arrayed thin films • Cooling devices in the MEMS Takahata and Gianchandani[16]
• Mask preparation in micromachining processes

Section 2 presents the working principle of R-MEDM process. The differences in process mechanics of MEDM and R-MEDM have been discussed in Section 3. Experimental characterization of R-MEDM process for fabrication of high aspect ratio arrayed structures is presented in Section 4. Section 5 presents key technologies for future developments and finally, specific conclusions drawn from studies conducted on R-MEDM process are presented in Section 6.

sec.title: 2 WORKING PRINCIPLE OF R-MEDM
sec.p:
The process involves formation of a plasma column analogous to EDM process. The plasma generated between electrodes due to ionization of dielectric leads to melting and evaporation of anode material. Semispherical cavities called as craters are formed on the anode surface. Although the size of individual craters is of the order of a few micrometres, high frequency of discharges helps achieve a comparable amount of material removal [17]. The diameter of fabricated micro-rods in R-MEDM process is less than the size of micro-hole diameter due to the interelectrode gap around the periphery of the workpiece. Figure 1(a) shows the principle of R-MEDM process. There are differences in the geometries fabricated in R-MEDM and MEDM processes. Extruded structures are fabricated in the R-MEDM (Fig. 1(a)), while a cavity is generated using a cylindrical electrode in MEDM (Fig. 1(b)). The process mechanics and response of MEDM and R-MEDM primarily differ due to variation in electrode geometries. Additionally, the electrode rotation, which typically assists in bringing about uniform distribution of the sparks over the anode surface [1, 18], is not possible in the R-MEDM while producing arrayed structures. Fig. 1
Difference in geometries of (a) R-MEDM and (b) MEDM [19]

sec.title: 2.1 Typical experimental setups
sec.p:
A typical experimental setup for the R-MEDM process consists of a plate tool electrode having an array of holes of desired geometry. The plate electrode is held on the machining table and a workpiece on a spindle head. Usually, the plate electrode (tool) acts as the cathode and the workpiece as the anode. The motion between the tool and the workpiece is controlled by a CNC controller. In addition, a continuous flow of EDM oil is maintained, which acts as the dielectric between the tool and the workpiece. A schematic of experimental setup for R-MEDM and a photograph of actual setup are shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b), respectively. A pulse generator supplies a pulsed DC supply between the electrodes. A spark is generated at the ionized state of a dielectric and removes the material in the molten/vaporized form from the workpiece. Fig. 2 (a)
Schematic of experimental setup and (b) picture of actual setup

Based on the positions of the electrodes, two variants of the R-MEDM are defined. These are normal and inverted R-MEDM processes (refer Fig. 3(a) and (b)). In the normal R-MEDM, the cathode is held on the machine table and workpiece mounted on the spindle head is free to translate in the vertical direction. On the other hand, the electrode positions are interchanged and a vertical movement is given to the plate electrode mounted on the machine spindle in the inverted R-MEDM. It is observed that inverted R-MEDM, shown in Fig. 3(b), is a better configuration as the machining time required for fabricating similar feature is lower than the normal R-MEDM (Fig.3(a))[20]. Fig. 3 (a)
Normal R-MEDM and (b) inverted R-MEDM

sec.title: 2.2 Key processing parameters in R-MEDM
sec.p: It is known that R-MEDM uses RC-based pulse circuit; therefore, the first set of key parameters includes the electrical variables of the circuit. In a RC-based pulsed circuit, energy per pulse (E), which varies linearly with capacitance (C) and squarely with voltage (V) [21], is given by (1)

Apart from these, the parameters which have significant effect are threshold, electrode feed, plate thickness, feature size, and the position of the electrode. A description of these parameters and their significance in R-MEDM process is elaborated in Table 2. Table 2
Processing parameters and their influence on process
Parameter Definition Influence on process response Reference
Voltage (V) It is the open-circuit voltage applied between the electrodes Voltage primarily affects the plasma characteristics, crater size and distribution, and exploding/imploding action of dielectric. Material removal rate, dimensional accuracy, and surface finish are affected by change in voltage Mujumdar et al. [22], Jahan et al. [23, 24], and Liao et al. [25]
Capacitance (F) It is the maximum electric charge stored at a given voltage before a discharge Pulse energy at the time of spark is directly proportional to capacitance. Effect of capacitance has a similar trend as that of voltage; however, its impact on the process is less than that of voltage Wong et al. [26] and Mastud et al. [19, 20]
Threshold (% V) It is specified in terms of percentage of open voltage (V) Threshold controls the sensitivity of the EDM process. Smaller the threshold percentage, higher is the sensitivity of the process towards arcing. Threshold affects the machining time, surface roughness, and the tool wear during process Mastud et al. [19, 20] and Jahan [27]
Dielectric It is an insulator which can be polarized by the application of an electric field Dielectric may be deionized water or kerosene-based EDM oil. Breakdown strength and viscosity affect the erosion rate, surface contamination, and surface finish on the fabricated structures Leao and Pashby [28] and Chen et al. [29]
Plate thickness (µm) Plate thickness is the thickness of the cathode plate which has micro-cavities formed on it Plate thickness controls the contact area between electrodes and affects the tool wear and dimensional accuracy Mastud et al. [20]
Feature size Range of dimension of the features to be fabricated Debris flushing is difficult as the feature size reduces. Arcing and short circuit increase while machining smaller features Mastud et al. [20]
Position of electrode Normal and inverted R-MEDM are two positions of electrodes defined based on whether anode or cathode is fixed during machining Machining time in inverted R-MEDM is less than normal-R-MEDM as debris flow is directed towards the fabricated structures Mastud et al. [20]

sec.title: 2.3 Capability demonstration
sec.p:
Previous studies have demonstrated the capabilities of the R-MEDM process in the fabrication of high aspect ratio structures on soft as well as hard materials like brass, W, AgW, and WC [2–6]. Most of the works reported in the literature used a normal R-MEDM setup. The differences in the setups arise from the use of different tool and the workpiece material combinations, as well as the geometry of the fabricated structures. A list of such studies with tool and workpiece configurations and the range ofprocessing parameters used is presented in Table 3. Table 3
A summary of process capability studies on R-MEDM

There are a number of factors which affect the response parameters of R-MEDM process. High dimensional accuracies, surface finish, and low surface contamination of the fabricated structures are the main requirements in critical applications in diversified fields (Table 1). In addition, the erosion rate should be high for the R-MEDM process to justify its productivity. Following are the typical response characteristics used while assessing the performance of R-MEDM process:
Dimensional accuracy: Interelectrode gap being an integral part of the EDM processes, dimensions of fabricated micro-rods are always less than the initial diameter of micro-cavity on a tool electrode. Ataper of range 1.5–3° has been observed on the fabricated micro-rods, which varies with the selection of processing parameters during machining. Side wear of the micro-cavity and non-uniform material removal during arcing are mainly responsible for the taper on the fabricated structures [22]. It is further observed that eliminating arcing using optimized process parameters, using low erosion tool materials, and adopting advanced flushing methods improves the dimensional accuracy of the process.
Surface finish: Crater size formed during sparking controls the surface finish. It is mainly affected by the electrical parameters in R-MEDM process. The surface roughness on the fabricated microstructure was measured in terms of µm Ra i.e. the arithmetic average of the absolute values of the roughness profile ordinates. The surface roughness on the fabricated microstructure varies between 0.3-2.7 µm Ra. The root of micro-rod is smoother than its tip. In the tip region, pitted surface with deposition of carbon is usually observed [22].
Erosion rate: MEDM and its variants are known for low erosion rates. The erosion rate in R-MEDM process is dependent on the physical properties of the electrode materials and the electrical parameters. Voltage and current (V–I) characteristics of R-MEDM process indicate that the arcing time (maximum 40 per cent) occupies a major portion of the machining time other than the normal machining and open-circuit times [19]. Due to high arcing, the erosion rate decreases with an increase in the tool wear and the surface roughness. In R-MEDM, the erosion rate of low melting point materials, such as brass and aluminium, is comparatively three to four times higher than that of the materials with high melting point and low electrical conductivity such as WC. Furthermore, in most cases, the use of ultrasonic actuation to either of the electrodes has proved to be one of the most effective ways of reducing arcing in the EDM and its variants [30, 31].

sec.title: 3 PROCESS MECHANICS OF MEDM AND R-MEDM
sec.p: Process mechanics of MEDM and its variants such as R-MEDM process are affected by both electrical and non-electrical parameters. It is thought that the variation in the geometries of anode and cathode can vary the process mechanics of R-MEDM process compared to the traditional MEDM. Voltage and current (V–I) signals show an effective way of capturing the mechanics of EDM-based processes [25, 32–35].

A comparative analysis of the process mechanics of MEDM and R-MEDM based on the voltage and current signals was performed by Mastud et al. [19]. Fig. 4(a) to (d) indicates a variation in the voltage and current pulses in MEDM and R-MEDM under identical processing parameters. In Fig. 4(a) to (d), A–B represents the open circuit time, TOC, B–C the normal discharge time (NDT), TND, and C–D the short-circuit time (SCT), TSC. During open-circuit time, electrode approaches the workpiece. Voltage is high and the corresponding current is low. During normal discharge instances, dielectric is deionized and sparking occurs between the electrodes. Debris entrapment causes passage of relatively high current even at low voltage levels during SCT. Percentages of NDT and SCT were calculated using equations (2) and (3), respectively. (2) (3) Fig. 4
Comparison of (a) voltage and (b) current signals in MEDM with (c) voltage and (d) current signals in R-MEDM process [19]

At any instance of time during machining, R-MEDM has a higher percentage of NDT than that observed in the MEDM process. The R-MEDM process is also seen to have a higher SCT than MEDM, indicating that debris entrapment poses a bigger problem in R-MEDM. In short, the overall stability of R-MEDM process is better than that of the MEDM due to higher NDT [19]. The R-MEDM process can also be operated at higher voltage and capacitance levels without any significant increase in arcing. Variation in the mechanics of R-MEDM results in higher material erosion rate compared to MEDM process for identical processing conditions. However, a large volume of debris generated in the primary machining zone (Fig. 5(a)) migrates into the secondary machining zone (interelectrode gap) and leads to localized welding along the surfaces of fabricated micro-features (Fig. 5(b) and (c)). Figure 6 shows a scanning electron micrograph of a micro-rod fabricated by R-MEDM process. The micrograph shows evidence of debris deposition on the surface ofthe micro-rod made via R-MEDM. This leads to a higher surface roughness on the micro-rods fabricated by R-MEDM compared to the cavities machined by MEDM under identical processing conditions. Fig. 5 (a)
Debris creation in primary zone; (b) debris migration in the secondary zone; and (c)debris attachment to the micro-pin surface [19] Fig. 6
Deposition of welded debris particles on machined feature (pointed by arrows) [19]

sec.title: 4 FABRICATION OF HIGH ASPECT RATIO ARRAYED FEATURES USING R-MEDM
sec.p:
Micromachining processes such as electrode generation through sacrificial block, wire electro-discharge grinding, micro-wire EDM (micro-WEDM), micro-EDM deposition, and micro-milling can also produce high aspect ratio single features or arrayed micro-features. However, their capabilities are different from that of R-MEDM process. In Table 4, the machining capabilities of these processes and their limitations are highlighted. With the exception of micro-WEDM and micro-milling, most of the other processes are best applicable for the fabrication of high aspect ratio stand-alone micro-features and are not quite capable of producing arrayed micro-features. Micro-WEDM cannot produce circular cross-section features. Micro-milling process results in subsurface residual stresses and tool wear which could be major impediments. R-MEDM, however, can machine high aspect ratio arrayed features of varying cross-sections and dimensions, as seen in Fig. 7. Being a noncontact process, fabrication of high density features is also possible. Fig. 7
SEM image of an array of micro-rods machined by R-MEDM [22] Table 4
Summary of capability of high aspect ratio feature fabrication processes

This section explores the application of the R-MEDM process for machining easy- and difficult-to-erode materials. The ease of electrical erosion is controlled by three physical properties of materials: thermal conductivity (λ), melting point (θ), and electrical resistivity (ρ). It is difficult to electrically erode a material possessing a higher product of the following three properties: λ, θ, and ρ. Accordingly, WC is difficult to erode as its λ.θ.ρ value is 0.0437, which can be an order of magnitude higher than relatively easy-to-erode materials such as aluminium (0.0045) and brass (0.0089). The values of λ.θ.ρ are 0.0092, 0.0207, and 0.0456 for Cu, WAg, and tungsten copper (WCu), respectively (Table 5). These materials are generally used as tool materials in R-MEDM process due to lower tool wear. Table 5
Erosion resistance of electrode and workpiece materials [45, 46]
Material λ (W/mK) θ (K) ρ (Ωm) λ.θ.ρ (WΩ)
WC 84.2 2597 2.0 E−07 0.0437
Copper 401 1357 1.70 E−08 0.0092
WCu 220 3773 5.50 E−08 0.0456
WAg 160 3683 3.52 E−08 0.0207
Brass 115 1173 6.59 E−08 0.0089

To generate a designed pattern of arrayed structures, it is necessary to develop holes on a plate electrode. Thin foils of conventional low melting point electrodes like copper, brass, AISI 304, as well as high melting point materials such as W and WCu, were used during R-MEDM. WCu produces high erosion rate, whereas WAg produced defect-free nanofinished surface with the lowest Ra and Rmax values [23, 47, 48]. Details of the electrode shape, size, and the corresponding arrayed features machined are presented in Table 3. R-MEDM process can fabricate arrayed structures as small as the smallest size of thehole that can be machined on plate electrode. Machinability is also a key factor in the selection of the electrode material. Machining accurate micro-holes is a key issue in developing new products for different applications. Micro-milling, micro-drilling, micro-EDM [49, 50], micro-wire electrical discharge grinding (WEDG), micro-punching [51], and laser micromachining [52, 53] have been used to machine required pattern of through-holes on the tool electrode (refer Table 4). The smallest feature of Ø30 µm and aspect ratio 50 has been machined on WC using R-MEDM process by Kim et al. [2]. Stable machining parameters obtained by Kim et al. [2] were voltage, 100 V, and capacitance, 650 pF. They also observed that the short bridge conditions could be relieved easily at 100 V. Zeng et al. [5] reported that a non-rotating electrode is the main cause of debris accumulation in R-MEDM. They analysed the effect of voltage, capacitance, ultrasonic amplitude, and hole spacing on R-MEDM process efficiency. As the dielectric bath vibrates at ultrasonic frequencies, micro-fluidic channels develop in the bath, which create cavitation effect and help in the effective removal of accumulated debris. A 5 × 5 microelectrode array of cylindrical micro-rods with diameter less than 30 µm and aspect ratio 8 has been successfully fabricated using the process. Optimal combination of processing parameters which yielded the shortest machining times was 150 V, 10,000 pF, and ultrasonic vibrations of amplitude 1 µm. The inter-hole spacing does not appear to be a significant parameter. In another study, Zeng et al. [5] have shown that the ultrasonic actuation to plate electrode results in the reduction of machining time by 2.5–3 times during R-MEDM of tungsten using tool steel as plate electrode. Also, the surface obtained in ultrasonically assisted R-MEDM is by and large free of debris. Ultrasonic cavitation, which is responsible for debris removal, involves formation of bubbles or cavities in liquids during the low-pressure portion of the wave cycle [24, 54, 55]. Stress shock wave of high frequency appearing at the discharge gap improves the dielectric circulation and effectively dispels the debris out of the machining zone.

A metal deposition technique based on the EDM principles but with a change in electrode polarities was used to create posts of Ø140 and height 2 mm [42]. R-MEDM process has been used by Yi et al. [3] to fabricate 3 × 3 and 4 × 4 arrays of 80 µm side and 600 µm height on copper, which was further used in micro-EDM of stainless steel foils for OTFTs. One of the shortcomings of existing micromachining processes such as mechanical micromachining andlaser machining is that they are not repeatable enough to produce very accurate arrayed micro-holes/cavities on the plate electrode. The cumulative errors introduced due to the dimensional inconsistencies of plate electrode, wear, and other process limitations (such as arcing at tip) affect the final dimensional accuracy. Consequently, the cumulative inaccuracies on the fabricated microstructures via R-MEDM may be as high as 50–60 per cent [20, 22].

sec.title: 4.1 Issues in the R-MEDM of high aspect ratio structures
sec.p:
Various improvements in the process are required before R-MEDM process can evolve from the research stage to a competitive manufacturing process. The improvements are specially required in the fields like electrode performance, process stability, accuracy, and quality of micro-features, as shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8
Research issues in R-MEDM process

The flushing conditions deteriorate with an increase in the surface area of machining in R-MEDM processes. During fabrication of arrayed structure over a large surface by R-MEDM process, frequent arcing in localized regions may cause burning of the thin plate electrode. In a true sense, R-MEDM is not a simultaneous machining process, as sparking occurs only along any one micro-feature that is being created. Takahata and Gianchandani [16] had improved the productivity of this process using a set of circuits between locally insulated electrodes to achieve simultaneous machining of micro-features. Since thin foils are used as electrode in R-MEDM processes, enlargement of micro-holes on them is inevitable as a tool wear of 10 per cent (by volume) is common in MEDM and variants. It results in the loss of dimensional accuracy and introduces a small taper on the fabricated micro-rods. These dimensional inaccuracies are further accentuated by frequent arcing along tip regions which removes a large amount of material, resulting in a loss of dimensional accuracy and a taper along the length of the fabricated micro-features. Temporary welds may form between electrodes due to short resistance paths formed between the electrodes and work surface due to debris entrapment. Energy-dispersive spectrum (EDS) analysis of fabricated micro-features in R-MEDM process revealed deposition of cathode material on the surface of the fabricated micro-rods. A high percentage of oxygen and carbon is also observed at the tip of machined feature [21, 56]. Minimal surface contamination of the fabricated micro-features is critical for typical biomedical applications of the machined features. Therefore, systematic improvements in R-MEDM process are critical to enhance the commercial and technical applications of this process.
The next two sections highlight the R-MEDM process characterization for the fabrication of high aspect ratio structures on brass and WC.

sec.title: 4.2 Fabrication of high aspect ratio structures on easy-to-erode materials
sec.p:
Copper and its alloys are the most extensively used electrode materials in conventional EDM and MEDM processes. A high erosion rate and good surface finish can be achieved in MEDM of brass using copper electrodes. Comparable melting point and high electrical and thermal conductivities of copper help to achieve low tool wear rate as compared to other electrode materials such as brass, graphite, and aluminium. However, WCu and WAg have excellent tool wear resistance but due to their low electrical and thermal conductivities, their erosion rate is relatively low [57–59]. The geometries of micro-cavities before and after R-MEDM process are shown in Fig. 9(a) and (b). Front tool wear produces a depression of height, h, with an enlarged hole diameter, Df, at the top. Side wear at the bottom of the plate enlarges the hole diameter from D to Db, see Fig. 9(b). Tool wear, being a gradual process, results in a change in the cross-section of the fabricated structures. Fig. 9
Geometry variation of the plate eletrode: (a) before and (b) after R-MEDM

During R-MEDM, it has been observed that the machining time increases by three to four times if the workpiece material is changed from brass to WC under identical processing conditions [19, 20, 22]. Moreover, copper electrode, which is suitable for R-MEDM of brass, exhibits high wear rate while machining WC. Consequently, it becomes unfeasible to machine high aspect ratio arrayed features on WC using thin copper foils. Machining characteristics of R-MEDM process have been evaluated for the fabrication of high aspect ratio structures on brass (easy-to-erode) and WC (difficult-to-erode) using different processing parameters. Process response of R-MEDM for these two categories of workpiece materials is discussed in this section. Taguchi-based experiments were performed to analyse the effect of voltage, capacitance, threshold, and feed rate on erosion rate, surface finish, and dimensional accuracy of R-MEDM on brass. Brass rod of Ø2 mm in diameter was used as anode and a 200 µm thick copper foil as cathode. The machined feature comprised a 400 µm square pillar and cylindrical rod of Ø200 µm up to 1 mm in length (Fig. 10). Fig. 10
SEM image of fabricated micro-rod arrays on brass [22]

Statistical analysis of the experiments revealed that the voltage and the capacitance were the most important processing parameters, which affect the dimensional accuracy of the fabricated micro-rods. For cylindrical micro-rods, the magnitude of dimensional error varied from 30 per cent to 60 per cent, whereas on square micro-rods, it varied from 15 per cent to 30 per cent [22]. Dimensional accuracy of the micro-rods improves with pulse energy, which is a function of voltage and capacitance. It is observed that the voltage has a larger influence on dimensional accuracy than the capacitance. Figure 11(a) and (b) shows that the variations in the dimensions at two levels of voltage are higher than the variations in the dimensions at two levels of capacitance. It hasalso been observed that the higher pulse energies can effectively dispel the debris particles by enhancing the imploding/exploding action of the dielectric. Overall, it helps to stabilize the process and improve the erosion rate, as shown in Fig. 12. Fig. 11
Effect of (a) voltage and (b) capacitance on dimensional accuracy of square rod [22] Fig. 12
Effect of voltage and capacitance on erosion rate [22]

The surface finish and the chemical composition on the surface of the fabricated micro-rods vary along its length. The voltage and capacitance are statistically significant parameters affecting the surface finish, crater dimensions, and the surface finish on the machined surfaces. A high surface roughness (above 3.5 µm Ra) has been observed on the structures machined at 80 V. R-MEDM process, being unstable at 80 V, causes frequent arcing and short weld formation, which results in high surface roughness along the tip of fabricated micro-rod. EDS showed comparatively higher percentage of carbon and oxygen at thetip of the micro-rods than at the root, as seen in Fig. 13. Fig. 13
Variation in the percentage of oxygen at the tip and the root of micro-rod [22]

sec.title: 4.3 Machining of high aspect ratio structures on difficult-to-erode materials
sec.p:
WC is widely used in cutting and mining tools manufacturing industries, dies, molds, and punches. In micro-engineering, WC is used in micro-tools, micro-punches, and micro-dies. This section highlights the experimental characterization of R-MEDM for the fabrication of high aspect ratio arrayed structures on tungsten carbide. Tungsten copper proved to be a better tool material as compared to copper in the fabrication of a 10 × 10 array of Ø80 µm pins having aspect ratio more than 5 using R-MEDM process on WC (Fig. 14). Fig. 14 (a)
WC 10 × 10 array of Ø80 and 400 µm height and (b) pattern of micro-cavities on WCu electrode used as a tool [20]

sec.title: 4.3.1 Effect of processing parameters
sec.p:
To illustrate the effect of processing conditions, experiments were performed using an inverted R-MEDM variant. Voltage, capacitance, threshold, feed, and plate thickness were used as processing parameters, while erosion rate, surface finish, tool wear, and dimensional accuracy were the response variables. SEM image of the fabricated WC micro-rods and the WCu electrode after machining is shown in Fig. 15. Fig. 15
SEM image of WC micro-rods (workpiece) and micro-holes (electrode) after machining [20]

It has been observed that as compared to R-MEDM of brass, R-MEMD of WC requires high pulse energy, advanced electrode materials, and effective debris flushing technique. In addition to voltage and capacitance, plate thickness was another important processing parameter which influenced the response of R-MEDM process. At higher capacitance and voltage levels, electric discharge can also occur at relatively large interelectrode distances. Hence, at higher levels of voltage and capacitance, an enlargement of machined cavity in MEDM was observed, whereas in R-MEDM it had opposite effect wherein the diameter of the fabricated micro-rods decreased [20]. Fig. 16(a) and (b) indicates the effects of voltage, capacitance and plate thickness on the dimensional accuracy at the middle position i.e. at 50%L (L being total length of machined microrod). It can be inferred that the dimensional accuracy on Ø200 mm rods is better than that on Ø80 mm rods at all the levels of selected processing parameters. This could be attributed to the higher probability of arcing along Ø80 µm rods than that along Ø200 µm rods due to inefficient flushing in the former case. Further, improvement in process has been observed at lower plate thicknesses due to easy debris flushing and enlargement of micro-holes. The net effect of these competing effects causes animprovement in dimensional accuracy with a reduction in the plate electrode thickness, as shown in Fig. 16(c). Fig. 16
Effect of (a) voltage, (b) capacitance, and (c) plate thickness on dimensional accuracy at 50% L [20]

Threshold and feed rate were found to be the statistically insignificant parameters that affect tool wear rate, whereas voltage, capacitance, and plate thickness are statistically significant. With an increase in pulse energy, the plasma temperature increases and a change in heat distribution pattern between the electrodes could occur, which results in an increase in tool wear rate, as shown in Fig 17(a) and (b). However, with thicker plate electrodes, better heat conduction may take place, thereby reducing the tool wear as shown in Fig. 17(c). Fig. 17
Main effect plots of (a) capacitance; (b) voltage; and (c) plate thickness on volumetric tool wear rate [20]

Surface roughness of the machined micro-rods measured at the tip and the root of micro-rods by Wyko NT9100 white light interferometer showed a variation of 0.53 µm Ra at low pulse energies (80 V, 10 nF) and 1.83 µm Ra at higher pulse energies (120 V, 100 nF). This can be attributed to the fact that the size of craters formed on the fabricated surface increases with the pulse energy. However, smooth surfaces were achieved at 20 per cent threshold values and small plate thickness (300 µm). Figure 18 shows that the surface roughness at the tip is slightly greater than that at the root. This is primarily due to a higher number of arcs experienced by the tip surface. Fig. 18
Surface morphology at (a) tip and (b) root of WC rod with Ø200 µm

sec.title: 4.4 Summary of R-MEDM process responses
sec.p:
A summary of the R-MEDM for machining of high aspect ratio arrayed features on brass (an easy-to-erode material) and WC (a difficult to erode material) is presented in Table 6. Table 6
Comparison of R-MEDM of brass and WC
R-MEDM of brass R-MEDM of WC
Processing parameters Voltage: 8–120 V Capacitance: <10 nF Voltage 8–140 V Capacitance >10 nF
Erosion rate 1.1–4.1 × 105 µm3/s 2.6- 3.5 × 104 µm3/s
Surface finish 0.6–3.5 µm Ra 0.5–1.6 µm Ra
Dimensional accuracy • Maximum error per cent in diameter is 60% •Improvement in dimensional accuracy with increase in voltage and capacitance • Maximum error per cent in diameter is 27% •Dimensional accuracy reduces with increase in voltage and capacitance

It is understood that variations in the erosion rate, surface finish, and dimensional accuracies for brass and WC reveal that the physical properties of material play an important role in the mechanics of R-MEDM process.

sec.title: 5 KEY TECHNIQUES FOR FUTURE DEVELOPMENTS OF R-MEDM
sec.p:
Key techniques for improving the stability of R-MEDM process are illustrated in Fig. 19. The advancements in these techniques will further enhance the capabilities of R-MEDM process to either fabricate high-density, high aspect ratio structures or surface textures over large surface areas. Ultrasonic actuation to either of the electrodes has proved to be an efficient way to increase the stability of the MEDM processes. However, the technique needs further development in R-MEDM. Also, developments in the power sources and control system will enhance the productivity of R-MEDM process and help enhance R-MEDM as one of the competitive micromachining processes. Fig. 19
Key technologies for future development of R-MEDM

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
Recent developments in the R-MEDM process have enabled the application of this process for fabrication of high aspect ratio and high density features on metallic surfaces. Recent improvements in the power sources, electrode materials, and debris flushing techniques have helped advance the capability of R-MEDM process. However, a lot remains to be done towards improving its productivity. Based on the extensive study of literature relevant to R-MEDM, it is inferred that:
R-MEDM can be performed in two configurations: normal and inverted. Of the two variants, inverted R-MEDM appears to be a better variant as it facilitates debris flushing due to gravity.
The minimum feature size which can be realized via R-MEDM is less than 30 µm and there is hardly any constraint on the cross-sectional geometry of the micro-features that can be fabricated.
Process mechanics shows that R-MEDM is more stable than MEDM and it can be operated at aggressive parametric conditions without hampering the process stability. R-MEDM process is mainly controlled by voltage and capacitance as they influence the material erosion rate and the surface finish of the fabricated features.
Higher material erosion rate is observed in R-MEDM; however, the welding of debris along the length of the structures degrades their surface finish.
A change in work material alters the process mechanics of R-MEDM mainly due to the change in their physical properties. Accordingly, machining of ‘easy-’ and ‘difficult-to-erode’ materials required different sets of parameters and has different complexities. Machining of an ‘easy-to-erode’ material is feasible at low pulse energy while machining of a ‘difficult-to-erode’ material such as WC requires high pulse energy. Higher pulse energy results in higher tool wear rate leading to loss in dimensional accuracy while machining ‘difficult-to-erode’ materials.
R-MEDM process has an edge over other competing micromachining processes such as block electrical discharge grinding (BEDG), micro-WEDG, micro-EDM of self-drilling as these allow fabrication of a single micro-pin and micro-WEDM and can produce rectangular cross-sectional arrayed micro-features only.
The R-MEDM process could be further enhanced using ultrasonic vibration of electrodes, magnetic force assistance, and improved power source.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENT
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the financial support provided by Department of Science and Technology, Government of India, to carry out this study.
